title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #974 asks: if power sums sₖ = Σ zᵢᵏ have infinitely many (n-1)-tuples of consecutive zeros, must the zᵢ be nth roots of unity? **YES** — proved by Tijdeman (1966).
mathContext: For complex z₁, ..., zₙ with z₁ = 1, the power sums encode algebraic structure. The vanishing of n-1 consecutive sums is a rigid constraint related to Newton's identities.

title: Configuration Type
content: A **Configuration n** is a function Fin n → ℂ, representing n complex numbers indexed by 0, 1, ..., n-1.
mathContext: Using Fin n ensures exactly n elements. The function type allows clean summation syntax via BigOperators.

title: Power Sum Function
content: The **power sum** sₖ = Σᵢ zᵢᵏ sums the kth powers of all configuration elements. These are the central objects of study.
mathContext: Power sums form a basis for symmetric polynomials. Via Newton's identities, they determine elementary symmetric functions and thus the minimal polynomial.

title: nth Root of Unity
content: **nthRootOfUnity n j** = e(j/n) = exp(2πij/n) gives the jth of the n equally-spaced points on the unit circle.
mathContext: The nth roots of unity satisfy xⁿ = 1 and are ζ, ζ², ..., ζⁿ = 1 where ζ = exp(2πi/n) is primitive. They form a cyclic group of order n.

title: Power Sum of Roots of Unity
content: For the nth roots of unity: sₖ = n if n divides k, else sₖ = 0. This geometric series property is fundamental.
mathContext: When n ∤ k, the sum Σⱼ ζʲᵏ = (1 - ζⁿᵏ)/(1 - ζᵏ) = 0 since ζⁿ = 1 but ζᵏ ≠ 1. When n | k, each term is 1.

title: Consecutive Zero Tuple
content: **consecutiveZeroTuple z k** means (sₖ, sₖ₊₁, ..., sₖ₊ₙ₋₂) are all zero — an (n-1)-tuple of consecutive vanishing power sums.
mathContext: Why n-1? Because n power sums (s₁, ..., sₙ) determine the characteristic polynomial via Newton's identities. Having n-1 zeros is nearly maximal constraint.

title: Infinitely Many Zero Tuples
content: **hasInfinitelyManyZeroTuples z** means for any N, there exists k > N with a zero (n-1)-tuple starting at k.
mathContext: This infinite condition seems strong, but Tijdeman showed even TWO such tuples suffice to force the roots-of-unity conclusion!

title: Essentially Roots of Unity
content: **isEssentiallyRootsOfUnity z** means z is a permutation of the nth roots of unity. 'Essentially' allows reordering since power sums are symmetric.
mathContext: Power sums are symmetric functions: Σ zᵢᵏ is unchanged if we permute the zᵢ. So we can only determine the configuration up to permutation.

title: Two Regular Polygons
content: For even n, **isTwoRegularPolygons z** allows the zᵢ to be vertices of two regular (n/2)-gons with the same circumscribed circle centered at origin.
mathContext: When n is even, there's more flexibility: two rotated copies of (n/2)-gons give the same power sums as the n roots of unity for many k values.

title: Turán's Conjecture
content: **turan_conjecture**: If infinitely many (n-1)-tuples of consecutive power sums vanish, then z is essentially roots of unity. This is the original problem statement.
mathContext: Turán posed this conjecture connecting the analytic condition (power sum zeros) to the algebraic conclusion (roots of unity).

title: Tijdeman's Theorem (Odd n)
content: **tijdeman_1966_odd**: For odd n ≥ 3, just TWO distinct (n-1)-tuples of consecutive zeros suffice to conclude z is exactly the nth roots of unity.
mathContext: This is far stronger than Turán's conjecture: finitely many (just 2!) tuples suffice. For odd n, the characterization is exact — no 'essentially' needed.

title: Tijdeman's Theorem (Even n)
content: **tijdeman_1966_even**: For even n ≥ 4, two distinct zero tuples imply z forms two regular (n/2)-gons. This is the complete characterization.
mathContext: The even case has extra flexibility from the Z₂ symmetry: rotating one (n/2)-gon by π gives another valid configuration with same power sums.

title: Main Result: erdos_974_solved
content: **Erdős Problem #974: SOLVED (YES)**. If infinitely many (n-1)-tuples of consecutive power sums vanish, then z is essentially roots of unity.
mathContext: The theorem wraps turan_conjecture with a clean interface. The proof is immediate from the axiom.

title: Newton's Identities Connection
content: Newton's identities relate power sums to elementary symmetric polynomials: k·eₖ = Σⱼ (-1)^(j-1) eₖ₋ⱼ pⱼ. This algebraic structure underlies the result.
mathContext: If z₁, ..., zₙ are roots of P(x) = xⁿ - e₁xⁿ⁻¹ + ... + (-1)ⁿeₙ, then the power sums determine the eᵢ. Consecutive zeros heavily constrain the polynomial.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_974_summary** packages both the main result (Turán's conjecture) and Tijdeman's strengthening for odd n into a single statement.
mathContext: The conjunction shows both the original problem (infinitely many) and the surprising strengthening (just 2 tuples for odd n).
